thread.title: Toddler beats the odds after developing rare tumour - 9news.com.au
thread.title_full: Toddler beats the odds after developing rare tumour - 9news.com.au

title: Toddler beats the odds after developing rare tumour - 9news.com.au
text:
Toddler beats the odds after developing rare tumour By 9NEWS 
A western Sydney hospital has today hosted a celebration to mark the end of one brave young girl’s battle with cancer. 
In November 2015, 23-month-old Grace was diagnosed with a metastatic rhabdoid tumour, a rare and aggressive cancer. 
The diagnosis was devastating for her family, from Dubbo in regional New South Wales, and marked the beginning of a 16-month battle of complicated surgeries, intensive chemotherapy and radiation. 
“The whole world collapsed,” Grace’s mother, Sarah Sharp said. 
“You don’t expect your seven-month-old baby to be diagnosed with cancer.” Grace rung the bell at Westmead, marking the end of her cancer battle. (9NEWS) Her parents are incredibly proud. (9NEWS) 
Dr Luciano Dalla Pozza, Head of Oncology at The Children’s Hospital at Westmead, said he had never seen a case like Grace’s before. 
“Grace had a very rare form of cancer and there was no defined best therapy for her,” Dr Dalla Pozza said. 
“We weren’t sure what the best treatment was.” 
Consultations with overseas specialists were made to develop a tailored treatment plan for the toddler. 
And although the outcome of the treatment was very uncertain from the beginning, Grace beats the odds. Grace was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive cancer. (9NEWS) 
Recently, a final CT scan showed the cancer, which affected her kidney and one of her lungs, was gone. 
Grace had her final procedure, to remove her central line, yesterday. 
Today a bell was rung at the hospital, marking the end of Grace’s treatment. She went through a 16-month treatment. (9NEWS) 
“It’s just the best day ever. It’s been a long time coming,” Ms Sharp said today. 
“She’s an amazing strong kid. All these cancer kids are.” 
“There’s no words that can describe how happy we are,” Grace’s father, Keiran Sharp said. 
“Words can’t comprehend how strong she’s been.” 
“We’re the proudest parents.” 
The family was surrounded by friends, who had travelled from the central-west town to celebrate, as well as Parramatta Eels players. 
“She’s done really brilliantly,” Dr Dalla Pozza said. (9NEWS) 
“One shouldn’t underestimate how strong children are. It’s really quite remarkable.” 
Grace will need to come back to Sydney for check-ups but for the time being, she’s enjoying her life cancer-free. 
“She’s got a pony and a chook and that’s her life,” Ms Sharp said. 
“She’s a farm girl.” 
Grace’s parents commended the Bandaged Bear Appeal and the Little Wings Foundation for helping them through the battle. © Nine Digital Pty Ltd 2017
